subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] QS-SAMPA: a proposed format for plain-text Quickscript
msgSnippet: I understand your confusion with Noon in typed script.  It is not necessary at all but it is aethetically more pleasing to see letters joined naturally, so I
messageBody:
I understand your confusion with Noon in typed script.  It is not necessary at all but it is aethetically more pleasing to see letters "joined" naturally, so I would much rather see Noon and Utter used if possible.  If no, then it not a bother.

Being used to reading Senior QS, I find it quite tedious reading Junior, so anything that moves towards Senior, as Jerome font does, is to be welcomed.

Moira

On 02/12/2007, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:

Terry Smithwick wrote:
>
>
> For the purposes of the News, there is no
> difficulty; the font need not do the work. After
> generating the QS text, scan through looking for Nun,
> remembering the previous letter. If it's in a list of
> good bottom-line connections, change the Nun to Noon.
> Or build the necessary correspondence directly into
> the dictionary.
>
> I see no problem using Noon even in Junior
> Quickscript.
> I would prefer that the news remained in Junior
> Quickscript, as that's my current skill level.
>
> To use a ligature rather than two letters, use the
> letter corresponding to the ligature. The ligatures
> (other than Earth) and half-characters could be mapped
> to accented letters, as many programs have methods of
> generating these without using laborious onscreen
> keyboards and such.
> For instance, to create é in Microsoft Word, press
> Ctrl-', e. (I just did it to paste here.)
> You end up with a string of SAMPA letters that can
> be passed as text in email. If someone wants to read
> this as QS, they can paste into a word processing
> program and change the font to Thoth-Sampa. This
> procedure could be automated. Hmmm . . .
>
> It would also be easy to create a table of
> character combinations that could be automatically
> substituted to generate Senior QS. Just write in
> Junior (plus abbreviations) as normal in SAMPA. Use
> the table to switch characters to their senior style
> when appropriate according to the previous or
> following letter.
> I see a problem with Ear; if this triple ligature
> is desired, you might need two passes through the
> text.
>

I agree that one can do everything you say with programming, and it
would not at all be difficult. But such a solution won't work
universally, because while I can process text with a program, not
everyone will have that program. If Moira or Paige wants to type in QS,
they are going to have to type in the message in Junior, cut the text,
run it through a program, and then re-paste it.

As far as ligatures go, one can certainly map them directly to a key, as
you suggest and as I have in fact done. But then a user has to remember
a lot more keys, and the beauty of automatic ligature tables is that the
ligatures appear like magic; type e + r (in Sampa QS), and you get Air.
Such an approach leaves the spaces in a font program free, as they are
supposed to be.

I'm a bit confused on the purpose of using Noon in the news. What would
it add? My understanding is that Noon is used to make connections easier
when writing. Since I don't write out the news, but have it generated by
a computer which does not have any more difficulty "writing" a Nun after
a letter than it does writing a Noon after a letter, I can't see the
purpose of using Noon.

Of course, none of this addresses what to do /3r/.

Paul
